habitat_description:
The northern limit of this species’ distribution lies in The Balcones escarpment of the Edwards Plateau in Texas, while the eastern slopes of the Sierra Madre Oriental in Mexico delineate the western boundary of its distribution (Judd 1985 as referenced by Natureserve.org). Conant and Collins (1991) reported populations of the reticulate collared lizard to occur in small areas in southern Texas, Coahuila, Nuevo Leon, and Tamaulipas, Mexico. 

This lizard is commonly found in well-drained terrain of shallow gravel, caliche, and sandy soils. It is absent from areas where other crotaphytids might occur (Behler and King 1979). Thorn-scrub vegetation, scattered clumps of mesquite and prickly pear. This species uses fence posts and branches of mesquite trees as basking perches.
